speech: It's completely okay to feel unsure about making friends. Social skills are learned over time, and you're not behind—you're just beginning your journey.
Taking small social risks—like saying hi or making eye contact—can lead to real change.
Friendship starts with kindness—toward yourself and others. Try to be present and curious when you meet someone new. That genuine interest often opens the door.
You don’t have to be the most outgoing person in the room to make friends. Being a good listener and showing empathy are powerful social strengths.
If you feel awkward in conversations, that’s normal! Most people feel the same way. Focus on small steps—asking someone how their day was can be a great place to start.
You are worth knowing. Even if it feels hard now, with time and practice, socializing can become easier and more fulfilling.
Not every connection will turn into a deep friendship—and that’s okay. It’s about being open and giving yourself the chance to connect when the opportunity arises.
Making friends isn’t about impressing others. It’s about finding people who appreciate you as you are. Authenticity is more powerful than perfection.
Try being involved in spaces that reflect your values and interests—that's where you're more likely to meet like-minded people.
It's okay if it takes time. Building real friendships is a gradual process. Be patient with yourself—you’re doing better than you think.
You can try asking what they like or bringing up some different things, like hobbies and stuff.
